metadata.case_name: Asa Ram v. District Board of Muzaffarnagar

facts.text: Asa Ram runs certain machines with the aid of power in premises within the Jalalabad town area since 1953-54.

Asa Ram did not take out a licence for running these machines for 1953-54 as required by bye-law 7 of the Muzaffarnagar Factories Bye-laws framed by the District Board of Muzaffarnagar under s.174(1)(k) read with s.106 of the U.P. District Boards Act.
Asa Ram was prosecuted for contravening the bye-laws.
Asa Ram admitted running the machines with power but contended that the premises being in Jalalabad town area, the District Board's bye-laws did not apply and no licence was necessary.
Trial Magistrate (Magistrate 1st Class, Muzaffarnagar) in Cr. Case No. 132 of 1955 dated February 14, 1955, held bye-laws not applicable to town area and acquitted Asa Ram.
District Board filed revision (Criminal Revision No. 17/18 of 1955), dismissed by Additional District Magistrate Judicial, Muzaffarnagar on July 13, 1955, agreeing with Magistrate.

District Board filed revision to Allahabad High Court (Criminal Revision No. 1724 of 1955), decided on May 11, 1956 by Single Judge who set aside acquittal and ordered retrial, granting certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.
Jalalabad is a town area since 1953-54.
U.P. Town Areas Act amended in 1934 substituting 'Town Area Committee' for 'Panchayat' throughout.
S.3(10) of District Boards Act amended in 1958 to exclude town areas from rural area, but at relevant time included them excluding municipalities and cantonments.

legal_issues.text: Is running of a flour mill etc. (machines run by Asa Ram with aid of power) an offensive trade?
Does the word 'regulation' used in s.26(a) U.P. Town Areas Act include the power of issuing a licence?
Does s.93(3) of the U.P. District Boards Act amount to a divestment of authority of the District Board in favour of the Town Area Committee?

petitioner_arguments.text: Bye-laws framed by District Board do not apply to premises within Jalalabad town area; prosecution bad.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.93(3) District Boards Act and s.26 Town Areas Act

respondent_arguments.text: District Board not divested of power post-1934 amendment as s.93(3) not correspondingly amended; 'Town Panchayat' vs 'Town Area Committee'; regulation does not include licensing but concedes it does.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.174(1)(k), s.93(3) District Boards Act; s.26(a) Town Areas Act

court_reasoning.text: Running machines is offensive trade under s.26(a) Town Areas Act, co-extensive with s.174(1)(k) District Boards Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Solicitor General does not contest; both bodies have power to regulate.

court_reasoning.text: 'Regulation' includes power to issue licences; District Board framed bye-laws under regulation power, not specific licensing power; distinguishes Mohamad Yasin case which was about fees, not licensing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court misunderstood Mohamad Yasin; Town Area Committee can require licences under s.26(a).

court_reasoning.text: S.93(3) bars District Board from exercising authority vested in Town Area Committee (even if termed Panchayat; substitution mere formal/translation); or alternatively, later/special statute (Town Areas Act) prevails over general (District Boards Act).
court_reasoning.key_observation: District Board power divested in town areas; Town Area Committee power prevails.

holdings.text: Running machines is offensive trade; both bodies have concurrent regulatory power initially.
S.93(3) divests District Board of authority in town areas where vested in Town Area Committee; Town Areas Act prevails.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Board, Hathras v. Behrey Narain Dutt
precedents_cited.relevance: Division Bench held regulation includes licensing; High Court disagreed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohamad Yasin v. The Town Area Committee, Jalalabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Misunderstood by High Court; about levying fees, not issuing licences.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shrimati Hira Devi v. District Board, Shahjahanpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Courts cannot fill legislative lacunae; different circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: King v. The Justices of Middlesex
precedents_cited.relevance: Later statute prevails over earlier repugnant one.

precedents_cited.case_name: Daw, Clerk of the Commissioner of Sewers of the City of London v. The Metropolitan Board of Works
precedents_cited.relevance: Later statute prevails where powers conflict between bodies.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. District Boards Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to regulate offensive trades via bye-laws; bar on authority in town areas; definition of rural area.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Town Areas Act, 1914
statutes_cited.relevance: Committee power to regulate offensive trades/callings; prevails over District Board.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar to s.106 District Boards Act on fees.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Village Panchayat Act, 1920
statutes_cited.relevance: Created panchayats; led to name change in Town Areas Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds District Board's bye-laws do not apply in town areas due to s.93(3); reverses High Court order for retrial; acquittal of Asa Ram restored as prosecution invalid.

key_quotes.text: 'Regulation' would include the power of issuing a licence-and very rightly so.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Overrules High Court's view on scope of regulation.

key_quotes.text: Nothing in this Act shall entitle a board to exercise within the limits of any ... town area, any authority which is vested in the ... town panchayat.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.93(3); basis for divestment of District Board power.

key_quotes.text: The law giving power to the body governing the smaller area should prevail over the law giving power to the body governing the larger area.
key_quotes.speaker: court
